@Seelion: Versioned, P2P File System. It has better support of static site than ZeroNet. (But no dynamic support.)

@Seelion: ipfs is a p2p file system that can be used to host web sites. ZeroNet is a full stack p2p website application. IMO, share huge video files -> BitTorrent/ed2k, share some photos -> ipfs, dynamic sites (blog with comments, forums, etc) -> ZeroNet, small static site -> ip2fs/ZeroNet, plain old static web site (works with JavaScript disabled) -> ipf.

I am using ipfs. ipfs is simple as a p2p file system. It is in a lower level compared to ZeroNet. ZeroNet is actually a web site market based on p2p network, and ipfs is a file system based on p2p network.
@Fido: Not blocked on my machine. Maybe its dns names are polluted by ISPs, try filter polluted DNS results.
@Mynameislegion: Replace `http://127.0.0.1:8080` with `https://ipfs.io` (the built-in http proxy/public gateway of ipfs network).

@ks: All sites with `.bit` are listed at ZeroName. Some search engines and proxies are likely to scan it.

ZeroMe is used by ZeroNet to resolve `.bit` domains (unless you specify other site with `--bit_resolver`). I guess @nofish or @HelloZeroNet has the private key.  Post your suggestions at <https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroName>

Japanese writing: Besides punctuation and symbols, Japanese is written in Kanji, Hiragana, and Katakana. Japanese vocabulary includes native words (main part, written in Hiragana alone), Chinese words (adapted in earlier history, written in Kanji, sometimes Kanji combined with Hiragana), and foreign words (mostly borrowed in modern times from Western languages such as English, a rapidly growing category, written in Katakana).

More on Kanji: The Japanese government published a Joko Kanji List (Kanji for Daily Use). Newspapers generally limit the use of characters to this list. Most kanji are associated with at least two readings:

- the native Japanese reading (the Kanji character is borrowed from Chinese, which represents a word in Japanese) 
- the reading that simulates the original Chinese pronunciation

Since the same kanji may come into Japan at different periods or from different dialect regions of Chinese, it may be associated with a multitude of Chinese readings.
Japanese dictionaries software: edict, kanjidict, enamdic. Lookup/frontend: lookup, kjdic (command line) gjiten (Gnome). Standalone (bundled dictionaries): gwaei (GNOME) kiten (KDE), tagainijisho

You should write "明かり" or "あかり" (mostly used in human name) for "brightness" or "light".  "明" alone is not a common word, at least in modern Japanese, it may be used for "enlightenment" (Buddha) or a dynasty of China, with different pronunciation.
I do not know a book of gentle introduction on Japanese syntax. I guess you can pick up one Japanese course book and just read its grammar part.
After downloading the binary and put it in '$PATH', run 'ipfs daemon' to start the service. Then check its status at <http://127.0.0.1:5001/webui>. Run `ipfs help` for help info.

@薄谷开来: 360 停就停了，可是现在还限速，也不提供快递硬盘过去拷贝的服务。本地要有备份，不能指望云盘。（这条我也没严格遵守，部分本地没有，所以现在也在24x7下载中。。。我这里移动端好像单独限速，也就是PC、移动端同时下载，速度能 x2. 不过感觉还是来不及。实在不行可能要多申请几个360账号转存然后租一些Windows VPS　同时下载，或者发动朋友帮忙下，不知道是否可行。

内置php解析器，Zeronet只有Python和JavaScript，用Python或JavaScript实现PHP不现实。

在我的电脑上看到的是Total:2719kB，User Data:2397kB，也就是说大头是User Data，User Data是用户（别人）在你的站点上发的内容，你sign & publish只是你自己的，不包括别人的。现在还没有管理界面。[#354](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/354) 手工的话，你需要改`data/users/[useraddress]/content.json`，然后以你的名义发布，`zeronet.py siteSign [yoursiteaddress] --inner_path data/users/[useraddress]/content.json --publish`
@Cxgreat2014: 那样一个是安装包会大很大，而且php的很多操作都是不安全的，如果要安全，需要js或python预处理，过滤不安全语句，这和用js或python实现php也差不多了。
@Cxgreat2014: 还有一种选择就是本地跑php，通过http通讯，不考虑安全性（因为只在站长机子上跑），缺点是不分布了。
@Cxgreat2014: 富文本编辑器肯定是用JavaScript写的呀，就算是PHP网站也得用JavaScript写这个，否则加粗一下就重载页面谁受得了？
